['Urtica - Genus name for various nettle plants, particularly stinging nettles.', 'Stingray (in context) - A common nickname due to the plant\'s ability to cause a "sting" upon contact with skin.', 'Causesprue - Another term used in some regions of Italy referring to the irritation caused by stinging nettles.', 'Urushiol-free - A descriptor for plants that do not contain urushiol, a chemical found in poison ivy and also present in nettles.', 'Nettle infusion - An herbal tea made from dried or fresh stinging nettles, valued for its health benefits.', 'Sting - The sensation experienced when the fine hairs on nettle leaves come into contact with skin.', "Urticaria - A medical term for a hive-like rash that can result from exposure to urushiol in plants like poison ivy or stinging nettles, although it's more commonly associated with other causes.", 'Nettle soup - Traditional dish made by boiling and consuming the leaves of nettle plants.', 'Hedge nettle - A common variety of nettle (Urtica dioica) often found in hedgerows or similar environments.', 'Nettlespan - The area where stinging nettles typically grow, such as moist and shady woodlands.', 'Stinging needle - A colloquial term describing the sharp hairs on the leaves of a nettle plant that can inject irritants.', "Urticaria complexus - Refers to stinging nettles' role in some natural remedies for skin conditions, though not directly causing urticaria (hives).", 'Nettle root extract - An ingredient used in herbal supplements and skincare products due to its purported anti-inflammatory properties.', 'Stingless nettles - A misnomer; stinging nettles have distinctive fine hairs that cause irritation, unlike non-stinging plants.', 'Nettle pollinators - Various insects like bees and butterflies that visit nettles for their nectar despite the potential risk of stings.', 'Sting nettle - Another playful term acknowledging the plant\'s nature to "sting" when touched.', 'Urticaria mimicry - The phenomenon where plants other than nettles cause symptoms similar to a sting or hive, confusing it with urushiol-induced reactions.', 'Nettle weed - A common name for several plant species in the genus Urtica that are related and have medicinal properties.', "Sting barrier - The natural defense mechanism of nettles' fine hairs, which can penetrate clothing to some extent but usually require direct skin contact.", "Nettle fern - A misleading term; while there is a plant called nettle-leafed woodfern (Dryopteris dilatata), it's not related to the Urtica genus and does not cause stinging sensations."]

['Crude oil - Unrefined petroleum extracted from underground reservoirs.', 'Petrol (or gasoline) - A highly flammable liquid used as fuel for internal combustion engines.', 'Diesel - Refined, distilled crude oil commonly used in diesel-powered engines and heating systems.', 'Lubricant - Substances used to reduce friction between moving surfaces by creating a thin film of oil or other fluid.', 'Bitumen (or asphalt) - A sticky, black, viscous substance that is derived from crude oil, often used for paving roads and roofing materials.', 'Kerosene - Refined petroleum product commonly used in kerosene lamps or jet fuel.', 'Synthetic oil - Artificially produced oils, designed to perform specific functions such as lubrication or hydraulic fluids for machinery and engines.', 'Waxes - Organic compounds extracted from plants or animals that solidify when chilled but melt upon warming, used in cosmetics, polishes, candles etc.', 'Solvent - A substance capable of dissolving another substance, often an oil-based product such as paint or varnish removers.', 'Motor oil (or engine oil) - Lubricating fluid that circulates through the moving parts of internal combustion engines to reduce friction and wear.', 'Gear oil - A lubricant specifically designed for use in manual transmissions, differentials or other gear systems.', 'Turbine oil (or turbo oil) - Lubricants used in gas or steam-powered turbines found in power plants or aircraft engines.', 'Cooking oil - Edible oils extracted from seeds, nuts, fruits or vegetables that are used for cooking and food preparation purposes.', 'Castor oil (or ricin) - A thick, clear to yellowish liquid derived from the castor bean plant, often used in machinery lubricants, electrical insulation materials, and pharmaceuticals.', 'Whale oil - Oil obtained from the blubber of whales that was historically used for lighting, heat, cooking, and as a machine lubricant.', 'Peanut oil (or vegetable oil) - A broad category encompassing edible oils derived from plant sources such as peanuts, soybeans or corn, commonly used in cooking and food preparation.', 'Olive oil (or olea europaea oil) - The liquid obtained by pressing the fruits of the olive tree, widely used for culinary purposes.', 'Bituminous coal (or lignite) - A low-grade coal that often contains small amounts of organic material, including hydrocarbons resembling crude oil when burned.', 'Biodiesel - Renewable fuel derived from plant or animal fats and oils through a chemical process called transesterification.', 'Shale (or black shale) - A sedimentary rock containing fine-grained organic matter that, upon heating, can generate oil or natural gas reserves.']
